SummaryOfEvents: On 16th December 1990 the 37 metre fishing boat NADINE was returning from fishing grounds in the gulf of Saint-Laurent, when she began listing to port and started to sink. Search and rescue operations were instigated but from the ten fishermen on board only two were rescued, two were not found and six corpses were recovered.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Grey River Rocks South Coast of Newfoundland
SummaryOfEvents: The Canadian ship « Zagreb » was en route from Harbour Breton, Newfoundland, on the night of 06 November 1990 to discharge the loaded catch of some 74,850 kg of wet fish. The ship was operating in reported poor visibility due to rain and snow, in easterly winds at 25 knots and moderate sea conditions, and is reported to have made an alteration of course to starboard on autopilot when south of Cape La Hune, intending to subsequently make an approach from the north into Ramea. While on this new heading, the ship grounded on Grey River Rocks and was total loss. The crew left the ship, in particularly successful abandonment using immersion suits and a liferaft, in the prevailing poor weather conditions, and were later rescued by a Coast Guard Ship.

Location: SouthEast of port Menier, Île d'Anticosti, Quebec
InitialEvent: Grounding and  Total loss of the ship
SummaryOfEvents:
The asphalt carrier «Rio Orinoco » en route from Curaçao, Netherlands Antilles, to Montreal, Quebec, experienced main engine malfunctions which the ship’s staff was unable to correct while the ship was under way. The ship anchored off Port Menier to effect repairs on 15 October 1990. However the next morning, the ship started to drag anchors in adverse weather conditions and was unable to either deploy the main engine or arrest the drag of anchors.
The Rio Orinoco grounded and was subsequently declared a constructive total loss.

Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life
Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents:
On 24th August 1990 the bulk carrier Silimna was anchored near the Port of Nishtun, coast of South Yemen, before sailing to Fujairah under tow of the motor salvage tug Simoon.
During her voyage the ship encountered heavy swell and bad weather, and she sank on 27 August 1990 at 12:43 hours.
At the time of the sinking, her crew was safely on board the salvage ships "Nice Tuna" and Tug Simoon.

Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: While attempting to swing after unberthing from section 109 in port of Montreal, the chemical tanker "Lake Anina" grounded outside the channel, opposite the berth. The ship grounded over a pipeline buried in the river bed.
The ship "Woodside I" with some 20 passengers on board was bound from Halifax to woodside  when, in a period of reduced visibility, the ship became involved in a near collision with the tug Tussle.

Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life
Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

Location: In the approaches to Halifax Harbour, Nova scotia
SummaryOfEvents: While the bulk carrier "Antwerpen", with a deck cargo of containers, was outward bound from Halifax on 4th April 1990, the container ship, "Lars Maersk", was inbound for the same terminal. Both ships had dangerous goods and pollutants potentially harmful to the marine environment stowed on deck. The weather on the morning of 4 April was inclement with a strong easterly breeze and fog which reduced visibility in the harbour and approaches to less than half a mile, constituting a 'near miss' scenario.

Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life
Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents:
Irving Forest, a Bermudian registered ship was on voyage from St John, Canada, on 6th January 1990, to Rouen, France, with a crew of 18 plus the wife of a crew member.  
Late on the 10th January, as a result of storm weather conditions, the ship took a starboard list of some 20 degrees with ingress of water into the starboard side ballast tanks.
Early on the 11th January, as result of the heavy list and the prevailing conditions, the ship suffered a total blackout which resulted in a loss of propulsion. A deck stowed container was lost overboard and subsequently three other deck stowed containers were also lost.

By noon on the 11 January the ship, in mid-North Atlantic without any power, was listing 30-35° to starboard. The Master sent out a distress call at 12:10 hours and as a result contact was made with BT Nestor, a tanker which was some 3 hours steaming time away from Irving Forest.
The crew decided to abandon the ship but during the preparations, the crew member's wife, the Chief Officer and a GP seaman were washed overboard. All three were later rescued by aircraft.

The remaining members of the crew subsequently left the ship by jumping overboard while hooked onto the ship's liferaft painter, the liferaft having been successfully launched into the sea.
All Irving Forest's crew, including the crew member's wife, were embarked aboard BT Nestor by 19:00 hours local time.

There was no loss of life as a result of this incident, but Irving Forest subsequently sank.
